name: Kim Yong-wan
summary: Kim Yong-wan was a Korean polymer chemist who developed advanced polymer membrane technologies at the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST). His research on separation membranes was applied in water purification and industrial gas separation, contributing to Korea's environmental technology sector.

name: Park Moon-gyu
summary: Park Moon-gyu is a Korean materials scientist at Seoul National University who has made significant contributions to nanomaterials and energy storage research. His work on nanostructured electrodes for lithium-ion batteries has been influential in advancing Korean battery technology, supporting the global leadership of Korean companies in battery manufacturing.

name: Cho Jang-hee
summary: Cho Jang-hee is a Korean biomedical engineer who has advanced prosthetics and rehabilitation engineering in South Korea. His research on myoelectric prosthetic hands and brain-computer interfaces has improved quality of life for amputees and people with disabilities. He has been a pioneer in Korean rehabilitation technology.

name: Shin Hee-sup
summary: Shin Hee-sup was a Korean microbiologist who contributed to the development of vaccines in South Korea. His research on viral vaccines helped establish Korea's domestic vaccine manufacturing capabilities, reducing dependence on imported vaccines and improving public health infrastructure throughout the country.

name: Kim Eun-young
summary: Kim Eun-young is a Korean stem cell biologist who has contributed to regenerative medicine research in South Korea. Her work on adult stem cell therapy applications has advanced treatments for cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases, helping Korea maintain its position as a leader in stem cell research.
timeline: Joined Korean stem cell research program

name: Kenichi Fukui
summary: Kenichi Fukui was a Japanese chemist who won the 1981 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his theories on the course of chemical reactions, particularly his frontier molecular orbital theory. He showed that the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) determine chemical reactivity. He was the first Asian Nobel Chemistry laureate.

name: Susumu Tonegawa
summary: Susumu Tonegawa is a Japanese molecular biologist who won the 1987 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering the genetic mechanism that produces antibody diversity. He showed that antibody genes undergo somatic recombination to generate the enormous variety of antibodies needed for immune defense. He later turned to neuroscience and memory research at MIT.
timeline: Earned PhD from UC San Diego
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Koichi Tanaka
summary: Already covered - see earlier Tanaka Koichi entry.

name: Osamu Shimomura
summary: Already covered - see earlier Shimomura Osamu entry.

name: Tasuku Honjo
summary: Tasuku Honjo is a Japanese immunologist who discovered the PD-1 immune checkpoint protein, leading to breakthrough cancer immunotherapy treatments. He shared the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with James Allison. Anti-PD-1 therapy has become one of the most effective treatments for multiple cancer types, saving thousands of lives.
timeline: Demonstrated PD-1 blockade treats cancer in mice
Clinical trials showed PD-1 immunotherapy effectiveness
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Hideki Shirakawa
summary: Hideki Shirakawa is a Japanese chemist who shared the 2000 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for discovering and developing conductive polymers. He accidentally produced a silvery polyacetylene film in 1977 that could conduct electricity when doped with iodine. This discovery created the field of organic electronics, enabling flexible displays and organic solar cells.
timeline: Graduated from Tokyo Institute of Technology
Earned PhD from Tokyo Institute of Technology
Discovered doping made polyacetylene highly conductive

name: Ei-ichi Negishi
summary: Ei-ichi Negishi was a Japanese chemist who shared the 2010 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions. The Negishi coupling, using organozinc compounds, enables the construction of complex organic molecules efficiently. This reaction is widely used in pharmaceutical manufacturing and materials science.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Pennsylvania

name: Akira Suzuki
summary: Akira Suzuki is a Japanese chemist who shared the 2010 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing the Suzuki reaction, a palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling between organoboron compounds and organic halides. The Suzuki coupling is one of the most widely used reactions in organic chemistry, essential for pharmaceutical synthesis and materials development.
timeline: Postdoctoral research with H.C. Brown at Purdue

name: Makoto Kobayashi
summary: Makoto Kobayashi is a Japanese physicist who shared the 2008 Nobel Prize in Physics for discovering the origin of the broken symmetry (CP violation) that predicts the existence of at least three families of quarks. The Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix explains why matter dominates over antimatter in the universe.
timeline: Published CP violation theory with Maskawa
Joined KEK (High Energy Accelerator Research Organization)
CP violation confirmed by Belle and BaBar experiments

name: Toshihide Maskawa
summary: Toshihide Maskawa was a Japanese physicist who shared the 2008 Nobel Prize in Physics with Makoto Kobayashi for their prediction of the CKM matrix explaining CP violation. Their theory predicted three generations of quarks when only two were known, and was confirmed experimentally decades later. Uniquely, he never traveled abroad before receiving the Nobel Prize.
timeline: Co-published CP violation theory with Kobayashi
Became director of Yukawa Institute, Kyoto University

name: Isamu Akasaki
summary: Already covered - see earlier Akasaki Isamu entry.

name: Yoshinori Ohsumi
summary: Yoshinori Ohsumi is a Japanese cell biologist who won the 2016 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering the mechanisms of autophagy, the process by which cells recycle their own components. His work using yeast to identify autophagy genes revealed a fundamental cellular process implicated in cancer, neurodegeneration, and aging.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Tokyo
Began autophagy research at University of Tokyo
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Selman Waksman
summary: Selman Waksman was a Ukrainian-born American microbiologist who discovered streptomycin, the first antibiotic effective against tuberculosis. He coined the term 'antibiotic' and systematically screened soil microorganisms for antibacterial compounds. He won the 1952 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, though credit was controversially contested by his student Albert Schatz.
timeline: Born in Novaya Priluka, Russian Empire (Ukraine)
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Georg Cantor
summary: Georg Cantor was a German mathematician who created set theory, one of the most important developments in modern mathematics. He proved that there are different sizes of infinity, demonstrated the uncountability of real numbers, and introduced transfinite numbers. His revolutionary ideas were initially fiercely opposed but eventually transformed mathematics.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Berlin

name: Srinivasa Aiyangar Ramanujan
summary: Duplicate - see Srinivasa Ramanujan.

name: Sophus Lie
summary: Sophus Lie was a Norwegian mathematician who created the theory of continuous transformation groups, now called Lie groups, which became fundamental to modern mathematics and theoretical physics. Lie groups describe symmetries of differential equations and are essential in quantum mechanics, particle physics, and general relativity.

name: David Hilbert
summary: David Hilbert was a German mathematician who was one of the most influential figures in 20th-century mathematics. He proposed 23 unsolved problems in 1900 that guided mathematical research for decades. He formalized geometry, developed functional analysis (Hilbert spaces), and proposed Hilbert's program for the foundations of mathematics.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Königsberg

name: Henri Poincare
summary: Henri Poincaré was a French mathematician and physicist who made fundamental contributions to topology, celestial mechanics, and the philosophy of science. He discovered chaos theory, laid foundations for special relativity independently of Einstein, and formulated the Poincaré conjecture, which remained unproven for 100 years until Grigori Perelman's 2003 proof.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Paris
Won King Oscar II's prize for three-body problem

name: Bernhard Riemann
summary: Bernhard Riemann was a German mathematician who made profound contributions to analysis, number theory, and differential geometry. His Riemann hypothesis remains one of the most important unsolved problems in mathematics. Riemannian geometry became the mathematical framework for Einstein's general relativity. He died of tuberculosis at age 39.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Göttingen under Gauss
Presented habilitation on foundations of geometry
Married and moved to Italy for health

name: Seki Kowa
summary: Duplicate - see Seki Takakazu.

name: Nikolai Lobachevsky
summary: Nikolai Lobachevsky was a Russian mathematician who was one of the founders of non-Euclidean geometry. He independently developed hyperbolic geometry in 1826, demonstrating that Euclid's parallel postulate is not necessary, opening up entirely new geometrical systems. His work was initially rejected but later recognized as one of the most revolutionary advances in mathematics.

name: Sofia Kovalevskaya
summary: Sofia Kovalevskaya was the first woman to earn a doctorate in mathematics (1874) and the first woman appointed to a full professorship in mathematics in Europe (Stockholm University, 1889). She made important contributions to analysis, partial differential equations, and mechanics. She proved the Cauchy-Kovalevskaya theorem and won the prestigious Prix Bordin.
timeline: Entered into marriage of convenience to study abroad
Earned PhD from University of Göttingen
Won Prix Bordin for work on rotating solid body
Appointed full professor (first woman in Europe)

name: Amalie Emmy Noether
summary: Duplicate - see Emmy Noether.

name: Evariste Galois
summary: Évariste Galois was a French mathematician who founded group theory and proved that there is no general algebraic solution for polynomial equations of degree five or higher. He developed Galois theory, linking field theory and group theory, which became fundamental to modern abstract algebra. He died in a duel at age 20, having written his revolutionary mathematics the night before.
timeline: Wrote final mathematical letter night before duel
Died from wounds in duel at age 20

name: Joseph Fourier
summary: Joseph Fourier was a French mathematician and physicist who discovered that any periodic function can be expressed as an infinite sum of sine and cosine functions (Fourier series). His Théorie analytique de la chaleur (1822) established the theory of heat conduction and introduced mathematical tools that are fundamental to modern physics, engineering, and signal processing.
timeline: Published Théorie analytique de la chaleur

name: Joseph-Louis Lagrange
summary: Joseph-Louis Lagrange was an Italian-French mathematician who made fundamental contributions to analysis, number theory, and classical mechanics. His Mécanique analytique reformulated mechanics using pure analysis without geometric diagrams. The Lagrangian formulation became the foundation of modern theoretical physics, and Lagrange points in celestial mechanics bear his name.

name: Pierre-Simon Laplace
summary: Pierre-Simon Laplace was a French mathematician and astronomer who made crucial contributions to celestial mechanics, probability theory, and mathematical physics. His five-volume Mécanique céleste demonstrated that the solar system is stable. He developed the Laplace transform, Bayesian probability, and the nebular hypothesis for the origin of the solar system.
timeline: Proved stability of the solar system

name: Chen Ning Yang
summary: Duplicate - see Yang Zhenning.

name: Abdus Salam
summary: Abdus Salam was a Pakistani theoretical physicist who shared the 1979 Nobel Prize in Physics for contributing to the electroweak unification theory. He was the first Pakistani and first Muslim Nobel laureate in science. He founded the International Centre for Theoretical Physics (ICTP) in Trieste to support scientists from developing countries.
timeline: Born in Jhang, British India (now Pakistan)

name: Ahmed Zewail
summary: Ahmed Zewail was an Egyptian-American chemist who won the 1999 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for pioneering femtochemistry — the study of chemical reactions at the femtosecond (10^-15 second) timescale. Using ultrafast laser techniques, he was the first to observe atoms in motion during chemical reactions, revolutionizing the understanding of reaction dynamics.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Pennsylvania
First femtosecond observation of chemical reactions

name: Aziz Sancar
summary: Aziz Sancar is a Turkish-American biochemist who shared the 2015 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for mapping the mechanisms of DNA repair, specifically nucleotide excision repair. His work revealed how cells repair UV-damaged DNA, which is crucial for understanding cancer and aging. He was the first Turkish Nobel laureate in science.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Texas at Dallas

name: Maryam Mirzakhani
summary: Maryam Mirzakhani was an Iranian mathematician who was the first woman and first Iranian to win the Fields Medal (2014) for her outstanding contributions to the dynamics and geometry of Riemann surfaces and their moduli spaces. Her work on hyperbolic geometry and ergodic theory was groundbreaking. She died of breast cancer at age 40.
timeline: Won gold medal at International Mathematical Olympiad
Died of breast cancer at Stanford

name: Shiing-Shen Chern
summary: Shiing-Shen Chern was a Chinese-American mathematician who was one of the greatest geometers of the 20th century. He developed Chern classes and the Chern-Gauss-Bonnet theorem, fundamental tools in differential geometry and topology. His work bridged the gap between geometry and physics and influenced string theory and gauge theory.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Hamburg
Worked at Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton

name: Kiyosi Ito
summary: Kiyosi Itô was a Japanese mathematician who developed Itô calculus, a framework for stochastic integration and stochastic differential equations. His Itô's lemma is fundamental to mathematical finance (the Black-Scholes model depends on it), probability theory, and physics. He received the first Gauss Prize in 2006 for his revolutionary contributions.
timeline: Born in Hokusei, Mie Prefecture, Japan
Published first papers on stochastic processes

name: Terence Tao
summary: Terence Tao is an Australian-American mathematician who is widely regarded as one of the greatest living mathematicians. He won the Fields Medal in 2006, the Breakthrough Prize, and the MacArthur Fellowship. His work spans harmonic analysis, partial differential equations, number theory, and combinatorics. With Ben Green, he proved there are arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions of primes.
timeline: Won IMO gold medal at age 10
Earned PhD from Princeton at age 21
Joined UCLA as full professor at 24
Proved Green-Tao theorem (primes in arithmetic progressions)

name: Grigori Perelman
summary: Grigori Perelman is a Russian mathematician who proved the Poincaré conjecture and Thurston's geometrization conjecture in 2002-2003, solving one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. Remarkably, he declined the Fields Medal (2006) and the $1 million Millennium Prize, saying the reward was irrelevant if his proof was correct. He lives in seclusion in St. Petersburg.
timeline: Earned PhD from Saint Petersburg State University
Published first paper proving geometrization conjecture

name: Jun Kondo
summary: Jun Kondo is a Japanese theoretical physicist who discovered the Kondo effect in 1964, explaining the anomalous behavior of electrical resistance in metals containing magnetic impurities at low temperatures. The Kondo effect became one of the central problems in condensed matter physics and led to advances in understanding strongly correlated electron systems.

name: Meena Alagiri
summary: Meena Alagiri is an Indian geneticist who has contributed to cancer genetics research in India. Her work on hereditary cancer syndromes and genetic counseling has helped establish genetic testing services in Indian hospitals and improved early detection of familial cancers across the subcontinent.

name: George Sudarshan
summary: E.C. George Sudarshan was an Indian-American theoretical physicist who made pioneering contributions to quantum optics, quantum field theory, and particle physics. He co-developed the V-A theory of weak interactions and the Sudarshan-Glauber representation in quantum optics. Many believed he deserved the Nobel Prize for his quantum optics work.
timeline: Co-proposed V-A theory of weak interactions with Marshak
Joined University of Texas at Austin

name: Jayant Narlikar
summary: Jayant Narlikar is an Indian astrophysicist who developed the conformal gravity theory with Fred Hoyle and proposed the quasi-steady-state cosmology as an alternative to the Big Bang. He founded the Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics (IUCAA) in Pune and has been India's most prominent cosmologist and science communicator.
timeline: Earned PhD from Cambridge under Fred Hoyle

name: Raghunath Mashelkar
summary: Raghunath Mashelkar is an Indian chemical engineer who served as Director General of the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR) and transformed it into a leading network of research laboratories. He championed Indian innovation policy, fought against bio-piracy, and helped revoke patents on turmeric and neem that exploited traditional Indian knowledge.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Bombay

name: Roddam Narasimha
summary: Roddam Narasimha was an Indian aerospace scientist and fluid dynamics expert who made significant contributions to turbulent flow theory, atmospheric sciences, and aerospace engineering. He served as chairman of the Engineering Mechanics unit at IISc and helped design India's Light Combat Aircraft (LCA Tejas). He received the Padma Vibhushan.
timeline: Published influential work on turbulent boundary layers
Contributed to LCA Tejas aircraft design

name: Raj Reddy
summary: Raj Reddy is an Indian-American computer scientist who won the 1994 Turing Award for pioneering work in speech recognition and artificial intelligence. He co-founded the Robotics Institute at Carnegie Mellon University and demonstrated the first connected speech recognition system. He has been one of the most influential figures in AI research.
timeline: Born in Katoor, Andhra Pradesh, India

name: Param Vir Singh
summary: Param Vir Singh is an Indian nuclear physicist who contributed to the design of India's Pressurized Heavy Water Reactors (PHWRs). His work on reactor physics and nuclear fuel management helped India develop indigenous nuclear power technology. He served at the Bhabha Atomic Research Centre and contributed to India's energy security.

name: Swaminathan Sivaram
summary: Swaminathan Sivaram is an Indian polymer chemist who served as director of the National Chemical Laboratory and made significant contributions to polymer science and industrial catalysis. His research on polyolefins and coordination catalysis has been important for India's polymer industry development. He received the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize.

name: Valerie Thomas
summary: Valerie Thomas is an African-American physicist and NASA scientist who invented the illusion transmitter, a device that produces real-time three-dimensional images using concave mirrors. She patented the technology in 1980, which anticipated modern 3D display technology. She also managed NASA's Landsat satellite image processing and contributed to space-based Earth observation.

name: Shirley Ann Jackson
summary: Shirley Ann Jackson is an American physicist who was the first African-American woman to earn a doctorate from MIT (1973). Her research on theoretical physics, particularly in condensed matter and optical physics, enabled advances in telecommunications including caller ID, call waiting, and the fiber optic cable. She has served as president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.
timeline: First African-American woman to earn MIT PhD
Became chairman of US Nuclear Regulatory Commission
Became president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute

name: Gladys West
summary: Gladys West is an African-American mathematician whose work at the Naval Surface Warfare Center was essential to the development of GPS. She programmed an IBM 7030 to create an accurate geodetic Earth model, developing mathematical calculations for the geoid that became the foundation of the Global Positioning System. Her contribution was largely unrecognized for decades.
timeline: Hired at Naval Proving Ground, Dahlgren
Refined Earth model used for GPS development
Inducted into Air Force Space and Missile Pioneers Hall of Fame

name: Patricia Bath
summary: Patricia Bath was an American ophthalmologist who invented the Laserphaco probe for cataract surgery in 1986, becoming the first African-American woman to receive a medical patent. Her invention used laser technology to quickly and painlessly remove cataracts. She also co-founded the American Institute for the Prevention of Blindness and advocated for eye care equity.
timeline: Born in Harlem, New York City
First African-American ophthalmology resident at NYU
Co-founded American Institute for Prevention of Blindness
Invented Laserphaco probe for cataract surgery

name: Kinji Imanishi
summary: Kinji Imanishi was a Japanese ecologist and primatologist who founded Japanese primatology and developed a unique theory of evolution emphasizing habitat segregation over competition. He pioneered the study of primate social behavior, identifying cultural behavior in Japanese macaques decades before Western primatologists. His ecological approach influenced conservation biology.

name: Eiichi Shibusawa
summary: Eiichi Shibusawa was a Japanese industrialist known as the 'father of Japanese capitalism.' While not a scientist per se, he founded over 500 enterprises including banks, insurance companies, and industrial firms, and was instrumental in modernizing Japan's economic and industrial infrastructure. He promoted the application of science and technology to Japanese industry.
timeline: Visited Paris Exposition, studied Western industry
Founded First National Bank of Japan

name: Masatoshi Koshiba
summary: Masatoshi Koshiba was a Japanese physicist who shared the 2002 Nobel Prize in Physics for detecting cosmic neutrinos using the Kamiokande detector. He confirmed the existence of neutrinos from a supernova (SN 1987A) and made foundational contributions to neutrino astronomy. His work opened a new window for observing the universe.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Rochester

name: Takaaki Kajita
summary: Takaaki Kajita is a Japanese physicist who shared the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physics for discovering that neutrinos have mass through the observation of neutrino oscillations at the Super-Kamiokande detector. His discovery that atmospheric neutrinos change types showed that neutrinos must have non-zero mass, requiring modifications to the Standard Model of particle physics.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Tokyo
Joined Institute for Cosmic Ray Research
Announced discovery of neutrino oscillations at Super-K

name: Sumitomo Masatomo
summary: Sumitomo Masatomo was a Japanese copper merchant and metallurgist who founded what would become the Sumitomo Group. He developed improved copper smelting techniques that increased the purity and quality of Japanese copper. His metallurgical innovations helped Japan become a major copper exporter and established the foundations of Japanese industrial metallurgy.

name: Taniguchi Norio
summary: Taniguchi Norio was a Japanese engineer at Tokyo Science University who coined the term 'nanotechnology' in 1974, defining it as the processing of materials at the nanometer scale. His paper at the International Conference on Production Engineering introduced the concept that became one of the most important technological fields of the 21st century.

name: Toyoichi Tanaka
summary: Toyoichi Tanaka was a Japanese physicist at MIT who discovered the volume phase transition in polymer gels, showing that gels can dramatically swell or collapse in response to small changes in temperature, pH, or chemical environment. This discovery launched the field of smart gels with applications in drug delivery, sensors, and artificial muscles.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Tokyo
Discovered volume phase transition in gels

name: Kotaro Shimomura
summary: Kotaro Shimomura was a Japanese seismologist who contributed to the development of Japan's earthquake monitoring network in the early 20th century. His work on seismic instrumentation and earthquake data collection helped establish the infrastructure that would eventually make Japan's earthquake early warning system the most advanced in the world.
timeline: Contributed to response after Great Kanto Earthquake

name: Imamura Akitsune
summary: Imamura Akitsune was a Japanese seismologist who predicted the Great Kanto Earthquake of 1923 years in advance. He warned that Tokyo was overdue for a major earthquake and advocated for earthquake preparedness measures. Though initially ridiculed, his warning proved tragically prescient. He advanced earthquake prediction research in Japan.
timeline: Predicted major earthquake would strike Tokyo
Great Kanto Earthquake confirmed his prediction

name: Omori Fusakichi
summary: Omori Fusakichi was a Japanese seismologist who developed Omori's law describing the decay rate of earthquake aftershocks. He designed improved seismographs and was one of the first scientists to systematically study aftershock sequences. Ironically, he died shortly after the Great Kanto Earthquake of 1923 while studying its aftershocks.
timeline: Formulated Omori's law of aftershock decay
Died shortly after Great Kanto Earthquake

name: Sekiya Seikei
summary: Sekiya Seikei was the world's first professor of seismology, appointed at Tokyo Imperial University in 1886. He was a pioneer of modern seismological research and created the first three-dimensional models of earthquake ground motion. He advanced seismic instrumentation and founded the Seismological Society of Japan.
timeline: Became world's first professor of seismology

name: Milne John
summary: John Milne was a British geologist and mining engineer who is considered the father of modern seismology. Working in Japan from 1876 to 1895, he invented the horizontal pendulum seismograph and established the first worldwide seismograph network. His work in Japan created the scientific foundation for earthquake study and monitoring.
timeline: Appointed professor at Imperial College of Engineering, Tokyo

name: Kuo Moruo
summary: While primarily a literary and political figure, Guo Moruo made important contributions to Chinese archaeology and paleography. He deciphered oracle bone inscriptions and advanced the study of ancient Chinese bronze inscriptions. His archaeological interpretations, though sometimes politically influenced, opened new understanding of Shang and Zhou dynasty history.
timeline: Published Studies of Ancient Chinese Society
Became president of Chinese Academy of Sciences

name: Xia Nai
summary: Xia Nai was a Chinese archaeologist who directed the excavation of the Ming Dynasty Dingling tomb in 1956-1958, one of the most significant archaeological excavations in Chinese history. He served as director of the Institute of Archaeology at the Chinese Academy of Sciences and helped establish modern archaeological methodology in China.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of London
Became director of Institute of Archaeology

name: Faxian
summary: Faxian was a Chinese Buddhist monk and explorer who made a 15-year pilgrimage from China to India and back (399-414 AD), one of the earliest recorded long-distance journeys. His detailed travel account Foguoji documented geography, natural history, and cultures across Central and South Asia. He traveled overland via the Silk Road and returned by sea.
timeline: Crossed Taklamakan Desert and Pamir Mountains

name: Li Bing
summary: Li Bing was an ancient Chinese hydraulic engineer who designed and built the Dujiangyan irrigation system around 256 BC, one of the greatest feats of engineering in the ancient world. Still in use today after over 2,200 years, this system tamed the Min River floods and irrigated the Chengdu Plain, turning Sichuan into China's most productive agricultural region.
timeline: Began construction of Dujiangyan irrigation system

name: Zheng Xuan
summary: Zheng Xuan was an Eastern Han Dynasty scholar who is known primarily as a Confucian commentator, but his works also contain important observations on mathematics, astronomy, and natural phenomena. His systematic approach to textual analysis anticipated scientific methodology, and his commentaries preserved much ancient Chinese technical knowledge.
timeline: Born in Shandong, Han Dynasty China

name: Lee Ho-wang
summary: Lee Ho-Wang is a Korean physician who discovered the Hantaan virus in 1976, which causes Korean hemorrhagic fever (now called hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome). This was the first hantavirus identified and the discovery solved the mystery of a disease that had sickened thousands of UN soldiers during the Korean War. He developed a vaccine against the virus.
timeline: Graduated from Seoul National University Medical School
Isolated and identified the Hantaan virus
Published discovery in Journal of Infectious Diseases

name: Cho Soon
summary: While primarily an economist, Cho Soon served as governor of the Bank of Korea and influenced Korea's science and technology policy through economic planning. His policies supported the integration of technology development with economic strategy, helping create the institutional framework for Korea's technological advancement.
timeline: Became professor at Seoul National University
Became governor of Bank of Korea

name: Kim Linsu
summary: Kim Linsu is a Korean scholar of technology and innovation policy who analyzed the mechanisms behind South Korea's technological catch-up. His research at Korea University documented how Korean firms absorbed and improved upon foreign technologies to become global leaders, providing a model for other developing countries' industrialization strategies.
timeline: Published 'Imitation to Innovation' on Korean tech development
Advised developing countries on technology policy
